results.title: To hell and back. Dr. Bavandra interview.
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
This video contains two programs from the Four Corners series. 1. To hell and back - schizophrenics talk about what it means to be a schizophrenic attempting to live in society. Treatment with drugs is discussed and the need for support from others is stressed. 2. Dr. Bavandra interview - Dr. Timotei Bavandra is interviewed about the coup in Fiji.

results.title: The Timber mafia [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Janine Cohen, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and TVE International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
A revealing profile on the illegal timber trade which is highly organised and operating on an international level involving several source countries throughout Asia, Africa and South America. Focusing on Indonesia, a major source country where it is thought up to 70% of all logging is illegal, reporter Stephen McDonell, with the support of Faith Doherty from the London-based Environmental Investigation Agency, attempts to seek out exactly how and where this illegal timber finally ends up. Starting in Kalimantan province, Indonesia, their investigative journey follows the trail from the illegally harvested timber in the rain forest national parks to neighbouring countries where the timber is “laundered” making it almost impossible to prove its origins. The wood is then shipped off to ports throughout Europe, Australia, China and Japan with no questions asked by the importers. This illegal industry which is destroying the environment and threatening the habitat of endangered animals and biodiversity of rain forests is also a danger to both those involved and those who dare to resist or prevent the warlords and timber barons from carrying out their business. Violence and corruption exists everywhere, even within governments and whilst trading regulations and jurisdictions remain complex and uncoordinated, the “timber mafia” will continue to rape the globe’s rain forests and devastate the ecosystems which inhabit these amazing ancient forests.

results.title: Surviving survival
results.creator_credit: Morag Ramsay and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
Today one in three people will come down with cancer before the age of 74 - 60% will survive. But it is the survivors who have to face life after cancer. Their victory over cancer is just the beginning of a long journey, where the survivor feels lost once treatment has ceased, that their life has changed and that they will always carry the fear of recurrence. Their psychological state of mind also impacts on the carers, often destroying close and longstanding relationships. This program examines the psychological after-effects for such patients and provides hope for the future for cancer survivors in the area of counselling and support. Contains some scenes in b&w. Reporter: Wendy Page.

results.title: Six pack politics
results.creator_credit: Martin Butler and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
Five years ago the small township of Aurukun on the west coast of Cape York, introduced a canteen which sold alcohol. In addition to the canteen the sly grog trade has also been allowed to flourish. Since then the level of violent crime and alcoholism has increased dramatically, destroying the Aboriginal community and ruining the future of the children. In 1991 the local council elections became a contest between the Drys, mostly women, and the Wets, led by those interested in profit, with the victory overwhelmingly going to the women. David Marr reports on the problems of this small community which mirror those of many such communities around Australia.

results.title: Sick at heart
results.creator_credit: Debbie Whitmont and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
The appalling statistics on the health of First Nations peoples in Australia - a male life expectancy less than that of Bangladesh, the highest risk of death by murder in the world, are a disgrace to Australia, and whilst there are those who care, there seems to be little hope for the future as many despair of any easy solution. Paul Barry and the Four Corners team table this generally pessimistic report.

results.title: The Shame
results.creator_credit: Virginia Moncrieff and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
This program discusses domestic violence and sexual abuse in the Aboriginal communities in regional and outback Australia, where Aboriginal women are fifteen times more likely to be hospitalised and ten times more likely to die from domestic assaults than their white counterparts. There is also a frighteningly high rate of sexual abuse of young Aboriginal children and as Patrick Dodson (Chairman, Reconciliation Council 1991-97) quite poignantly remarks “At stake is the survival of Aboriginal people”. Rather than laying blame, reporter Liz Jackson attempts to find out why domestic abuse is so prevalent and what, if anything, is being done to improve conditions for the Aboriginal communities. Unemployment, alcohol abuse, boredom, low self-esteem, and cultural rituals contribute, it would appear, to the Aboriginal male aggression towards their family, and particularly their wives. Through interviews and personal stories, “The Shame” provides an insight into this most disturbing and tragic situation which exists among the indigenous people of Australia.

results.title: Seeing is believing
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
A “Four Corners” program which discusses the different attitudes people have towards television and newspapers. The editor of The Age newspaper gives his views on the reason for the poor credibility rating of newspapers as against that of television. Includes commentary by Graeme Perkins, Mike Willesee, John Temple and Ross Symonds.
results.description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
A “Four Corners” program which discusses the different attitudes people have towards television and newspapers. The editor of The Age newspaper gives his views on the reason for the poor credibility rating of newspapers as against that of television. Includes commentary by Graeme Perkins, Mike Willesee, John Temple and Ross Symonds.

results.title: New settlers of the inland
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
This program looks at the people who are forming alternative settlements in the Rainbow Region of Ne South Wales. Examines their motivation for leaving the city and shows the lifestyle they are now pursuing.

results.title: Four Corners: The Moonlight State
results.creator_credit: Shaun Hoyt and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Despite denials by the Minister for Local Government Russ Hinze, Police Commissioner Terence Lewis, and Police Minister, Bill Gunn, widespread police corruption is evident throughout Queensland. Brothels masquerading as massage parlours with illegal gambling inhouse and drug trafficking are shown. Persons prominent in the criminal activities are named. This program was a major contributor to the setting up of the Fitzgerald Enquiry into Corruption in Queensland. Presenter: Andrew Olle. Reporter: Chris Masters.
Episode of the ABC TV program Four Corners, aired 11/5/1987.
results.description:

results.title: Minus thirteen and counting
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
A probe into a growing social problem, the invasion of privacy resulting from developments in official and private surveillance of the individual. The title refers to Orwell’s novel, ‘1984’.
